headline: MSc in Engineering | Technical University of Denmark, Bioinformatics I AI in Healtcare
summary: Recently finished my MSc in Engineering at the Technical University of Denmark in Bioinformatics and Systems Biology, with a specialization in Deep Learning for Healthcare. I have a strong passion for coding and machine learning, complemented by a solid foundation in biology and microbiology.

projects_topics: Enabling Transfer Learning and Harmonization of Electronic Health Record Data for Deep Learning Prediction Models
Predicting transmembrane protein topology from 3D structure using inverse folding structure representations
Comparative analysis of encoding methods for allergenicity prediction based on deep learning
Bacillus subtilis and Pseudomonas spp. antagonism and division of labor in polymicrobial biofilms

projects.name: Enabling Transfer Learning and Harmonization of Electronic Health Record Data for Deep Learning Prediction Models
projects.description: Domain-specific foundation models for healthcare have expanded rapidly in recent years, yet foundation models for critical care time series remain relatively unexplored due to the limited size and availability of datasets. This work introduces an early-stage pre-trained foundation model for critical care time-series trained on pooled electronic health record datasets.

projects.name: Predicting transmembrane protein topology from 3D structure using inverse folding structure representations
projects.description: This project investigates whether protein topology can be predicted more accurately using 3D protein structure as opposed to current sequence based methods. The project relies on the current advancements within protein structure prediction as the 3D structures are obtained from AlphaFold DB. The structures will be embedded using the pre-trained Graph Neural Network (GNN) ESM-IF1. On the other hand, the project further focuses on training different graph neural networks from scratch, to get a comparison of pre-trained and trained GNN‚Äôs. The aim of the project is to determine the optimal use of GNN‚Äôs for the protein topology prediction task. Show less

projects.name: Comparative analysis of encoding methods for allergenicity prediction based on deep learning
projects.description: Allergenicity prediction plays a crucial role in assessing the potential allergenic properties of novel proteins in the food, pharmaceutical, and health technology industry. Recent advancements in deep learning techniques have promising performance dealing with sequence and image data. Additionally, the prediction of protein allergenicity has been improved by deploying deep learning frameworks on allergen dataset. This project focuses on a comparative analysis of different encoding methods. The encoding methods compared are one-hot encoding, BLOSUM62 and ESM-2 encoding (Language model). The project aims to identify the methodology best suited for allergenicity prediction. Show less

projects.name: Bacillus subtilis and Pseudomonas spp. antagonism and division of labor in polymicrobial biofilms
projects.description: This project investigated biofilm-related interactions between different bacterial species. Biofilms are extremely competitive environments where microbial cells benefit from collective actions, which enhance their survival. When pathogens form biofilm and cause disease it becomes a serious biomedical challenge. Probiotic bacteria have a great potential for treatment and prevention of biofilm-related infections. In nature, most biofilms are extremely diverse, and coexistence in a biofilm allows different species to interact. Their symbiosis can be either cooperative, neutral or competitive and knowledge about interactions, positive as well as negative, might have great biomedical applications. Show less

projects.name: Physiological characterization of Lactobacillus strains
projects.description: The vaginal microbiota has important implications for women‚Äôs health and affects the risk of yeast, viral and bacterial infections, such as bacterial vaginosis (BV). Dysbiosis in the vaginal niche furthermore impacts fertility and is associated with miscarriages and preterm birth, as well as with a higher susceptibility for sexually transmitted infections (STIs). BV affects up to 58% of women worldwide and is characterized by varying symptoms and the presence of an anaerobic mixed-species microbiota. Currently, neither effective prognostics nor therapeutics exist to tackle this challenge as standard treatment with antibiotics has a high recurrence rate as it effectively removes the infection, but does not restore a healthy microbiome. Vaginal communities dominated by Lactobacillus species are generally associated with health. Through metabolism of currently not fully known carbon sources lactobacilli produce lactic acid, which lowers the vaginal pH and excludes unwanted species. Ensuring a strong Lactobacillus colonization might therefore have therapeutic potential but the underlying mechanisms behind shifts between healthy and BV microbiomes are still poorly understood. In that connection, a more thorough understanding of the mode of action of the vaginal microbiota is essential. This study therefore investigates the metabolism of several vaginal Lactobacillus strains by examining their carbon source utilization via Analytical profile index (API) tests and Biolog experiments. Show less
